quiz.name: 2026 CFA Program LI Mock Exam 4 Session 1
quiz.subtopic: 2026 CFA Program LI Mock Exam 4 Session 1
instructions:
CFA Level 1 Mock Exam Instructions

This CFA Level I mock exam (Session 1) is in English and contains 90 multiple-choice questions. You will have 2 hours and 15 minutes to complete the exam and review your answers. 

Before You Begin

Please note the following in regards to this examination:

  • International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) apply unless otherwise noted.
  • "The Code" refers to the CFA Institute Code of Ethics.
  • "The Standards" refers to the CFA Institute Standards of Professional Conduct.
  • "GIPS® standards" refers to the Global Investment Performance Standards.

How to Answer Questions

  • Each question is numbered and includes multiple-choice options (lettered A, B, C).
  • For each question:
    • Decide which answer is best.
    • Select the corresponding letter.
    • Click 'Next' to move to the next question.
  • You may:
    • Select only one answer per question.
    • Skip questions or return to questions by selecting the ‘Previous’ or the ‘Next’ buttons.

After Completing the Exam

  • Click 'Submit' when you are finished.
  • Once submitted, you may review all questions and your selected answers.
  • Only selected responses will be scored.
  • Your score will reflect the number of correct answers only.
    • No penalty for incorrect answers.
    • It is to your advantage to answer every question, even if you are unsure of the correct answer.
  • If you finish early, use the remaining time to review questions you are unsure about.

Click the 'Begin' button when you are ready to start the mock exam.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Ethics-Hambusch-09
entry.itemBody: Max Ohn, CFA, works as a client advisor for a small firm. He has established a referral program with a real estate agency. Ohn refers clients to the real estate agency and the real estate agency refers clients to Ohn. Because the real estate agency does not compete with Ohn's employer and because the arrangement benefits Ohn's firm, he omits disclosure of the arrangement to his firm. Ohn diligently discloses the referral arrangement to all referred clients after they become firm clients. Has Ohn most likely violated the Standard relating to referral fees?

answerFeedback.157183bb-769d-4bfa-b6ec-9b36740fd1a2: Correct because Standard VI (C), Referral Fees, states that members and candidates must disclose to their employer, clients, and prospective clients, as appropriate, any compensation, consideration, or benefit received from or paid to others for the recommendation of products or services. Members and candidates must disclose when they pay a fee or provide compensation to others who have referred prospective clients to the member or candidate. Therefore, Ohn is required to disclose the arrangement to his employer. Further, he is required to disclose the arrangement before, not after, a referral becomes a client: Appropriate disclosure means that members and candidates must advise the client or prospective client, before entry into any formal agreement for services, of any benefit given or received for the recommendation of any services provided by the member or candidate.
answerFeedback.b93da8ae-2fed-40bd-bfc3-591fd166ca99: Incorrect because Standard VI (C), Referral Fees, states that members and candidates must disclose to their employer, clients, and prospective clients, as appropriate, any compensation, consideration, or benefit received from or paid to others for the recommendation of products or services. Members and candidates must disclose when they pay a fee or provide compensation to others who have referred prospective clients to the member or candidate. Therefore, Ohn is required to disclose the arrangement to his employer. Further, he is required to disclose the arrangement before, not after, a referral becomes a client.
answerFeedback.f5982971-a0d3-4881-a933-c7effd207d24: Incorrect because Standard VI (C), Referral Fees, states that members and candidates must disclose to their employer, clients, and prospective clients, as appropriate, any compensation, consideration, or benefit received from or paid to others for the recommendation of products or services. Members and candidates must disclose when they pay a fee or provide compensation to others who have referred prospective clients to the member or candidate. Therefore, Ohn is required to disclose the arrangement to his employer. Further, he is required to disclose the arrangement before, not after, a referral becomes a client.

choices.itemBody: B. Yes, only by omitting disclosure of the arrangement to his firm
C. Yes, by omitting disclosure of the arrangement to his firm and by disclosing the referral arrangement to referred clients after they become firm clients

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Ethics-Klaschka-18
entry.itemBody: A member, who is an independent analyst, is approached by two small companies to write issuer-paid research report. Company 1 proposes to pay a flat fee plus stock warrants to the member. Company 2 requires the member to obtain approval prior to publishing the reports. The member most likely violates the Standards if the member agrees to write reports for:

answerFeedback.135c0619-208d-436f-9542-42a67337817e: Correct because according to Standard I(B) Independence and Objectivity, Members and Candidates must use reasonable care and judgment to achieve and maintain independence and objectivity in their professional activities. Members and Candidates must not offer, solicit, or accept any gift, benefit, compensation, or consideration that reasonably could be expected to compromise their own or another's independence and objectivity.  With regards to issuer-paid research, best practice is for independent analysts, prior to writing their reports, to negotiate only a flat fee for their work that is not linked to their conclusions or recommendations. Furthermore, prior approval of the research reports by the covered company before they are published will impact the member's objectivity.
answerFeedback.15843981-ea9f-4abb-9229-00d917a3803d: Incorrect because according to Standard I(B) Independence and Objectivity, with regards to issuer-paid research, best practice is for independent analysts, prior to writing their reports, to negotiate only a flat fee for their work that is not linked to their conclusions or recommendations. Therefore, accepting the compensation from Company 1 will result in a violation. Furthermore, accepting the compensation from Company 2 will also result in a violation. According to Standard I(B) Independence and Objectivity, Members and Candidates must use reasonable care and judgment to achieve and maintain independence and objectivity in their professional activities. Prior approval of the research reports by the covered company before they are published will impact the member's objectivity.
answerFeedback.a6d07083-b9de-4366-9784-dc007cb2106b: Incorrect because according to Standard I(B) Independence and Objectivity, Members and Candidates must use reasonable care and judgment to achieve and maintain independence and objectivity in their professional activities. Prior approval of the research reports by the covered company before they are published will impact the member's objectivity. Therefore, accepting the compensation from Company 2 will result in a violation. Furthermore, accepting the compensation from Company 1 will also result in a violation. According to Standard I(B) Independence and Objectivity, with regards to issuer-paid research, best practice is for independent analysts, prior to writing their reports, to negotiate only a flat fee for their work that is not linked to their conclusions or recommendations.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Ethics-Lee-12
entry.itemBody: Toni Lynn, CFA, is a research analyst. Lynn relies on her colleagues to determine whether the third-party research she uses is sound. Lynn also uses content from personal blogs and social media websites for her research after concluding it is sound. Has Lynn most likely violated the Standard relating to diligence and reasonable basis?

answerFeedback.4a14b362-cc0c-4152-a192-0550988908a7: Incorrect because Lynn most likely has not violated Standard V(A), Diligence and Reasonable Basis, as described in the response rationale of the correct answer.
answerFeedback.53e62a45-ac5f-485e-9a20-79cbb121569b: Incorrect because Lynn most likely has not violated Standard V(A), Diligence and Reasonable Basis, as described in the response rationale of the correct answer.
answerFeedback.da8d9ec0-c903-4d4d-b632-bf83910aba7a:
Correct because according to Standard V(A), Diligence and Reasonable Basis, a member or candidate may rely on others in his or her firm to determine whether secondary or third-party research is sound and use the information in good faith unless the member or candidate has reason to question its validity or the processes and procedures used by those responsible for the research. 

Also, according to Standard V(A), Diligence and Reasonable basis, the sources of the information and data will influence the level of the review a member or candidate must undertake. Information and data taken from internet sources, such as personal blogs, independent research aggregation websites, or social media websites, likely require a greater level of review than information from more established research organizations. Because relying on her colleagues to check third-party research is permitted; and Standard V(A) does not prohibit using personal blogs and social media websites for her research, Lynn has not violated Standard V(A).

choices.itemBody: B. Yes, by using content from personal blogs and social media websites for her research
C. Yes, by relying on her colleagues to determine whether the third-party research is sound

entry.title: ITEM_20170420173
entry.itemBody: Teresa Avila, CFA, is a micro cap investment analyst at a hedge fund. The fund requires Avila to hold any securities she recommends for the fund in her own account as well. Because Avila has such a small account, whenever she trades for her own portfolio she combines the transactions with those of the hedge fund so she is sure to have her account aligned with the fund. Has Avila most likely violated any CFA Institute Standards of Professional Conduct?

answerFeedback.34a4a448-b5a1-40d1-81bc-70bc97028ef6: Incorrect because Avila has not violated Standard I(D), Misconduct.
answerFeedback.981d45da-48c7-4fba-850d-0bf268208678: Incorrect because Avila has violated Standard VI(B), Priority of Transactions.
answerFeedback.c27a8869-6f55-40c8-a053-89604c06d972: Correct because Standard VI(B), Priority of Transactions, requires that investment transactions for clients and employers have priority over transactions in which members have beneficial ownership. By executing her own accounts transactions with those of the hedge fund the analyst has violated this Standard as micro cap securities can be thinly traded and easily influenced by changes in the volume of activity. So the analyst may benefit when she combines her transactions with the hedge funds and she should let the fund execute its orders before she makes changes to her account.

choices.itemBody: B. Yes, the Standard relating to misconduct
C. Yes, the Standard relating to priority of transactions

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Ethics-Agarwal-09
entry.itemBody: Kush Shah, CFA, is the chief investment officer of an investment firm. Shah discovers during a routine review of the firm's trading system that the firm erroneously bought shares of IY Steel (IYS) for several clients. Shah immediately sells IY shares and realises significant profits for the clients. Later, Shah outsources a portion of the clients' portfolios to an external manager. Shah does not notify the firm's clients about the external manager because the fund's stock selection process remains unchanged. Shah has violated the Standards because he failed to notify the clients:

answerFeedback.10bac64b-d568-4f80-909e-60e4024d0209: Incorrect because Shah violated the Standard by failing to notify clients both about the erroneous purchase of IY shares and about outsourcing a portion of the clients' portfolios to an external manager, as described in the response rationale to the correct answer.
answerFeedback.1e4f2ec5-2b00-42eb-9cca-6e74f6dcc102: Correct because according to Standard V(B) relating to Communication with Clients and Prospective Clients, the member or candidate must keep clients and other interested parties informed on an ongoing basis about changes to the investment processes, specially newly identified significant risks and limitations. Thus, the outsourcing to the external manager should be notified to clients. Also Shah, violated V(B) by not disclosing the error in the trading system. Clients should have been informed about the error and the corrective actions the firm was undertaking on their behalf. Hence, both actions constitute a violation of the Standards.
answerFeedback.9a7a83ba-fd69-45a0-8ee2-cb4cb9b962d0: Incorrect because Shah violated the Standard by failing to notify clients both about the erroneous purchase of IY shares and about outsourcing a portion of the clients' portfolios to an external manager, as described in the response rationale to the correct answer.

choices.itemBody: A. only about the erroneous purchase of IY shares.
B. only about outsourcing a portion of the clients' portfolios to an external manager.
C. about the erroneous purchase of IY shares and about outsourcing a portion of the clients' portfolios to an external manager.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Ethics-Augulyte-17
entry.itemBody: The Standard relating to additional compensation arrangements requires members to disclose which of the following that might create a conflict with their employer's interests?

answerFeedback.2d9124b8-b971-4af9-b0cc-05ff615d8496: Incorrect because according to Standard IV (B), Additional Compensation Arrangements, members must obtain permission from their employer before accepting compensation or other benefits from third parties for the services rendered to the employer or for any services that might create a conflict with their employer’s interest. Compensation and benefits include direct compensation by the client and any indirect compensation or other benefits received from third parties.
answerFeedback.78d4bfba-d8bc-438d-bd15-42c9aa7e7ae2: Correct because according to Standard IV (B), Additional Compensation Arrangements, members must obtain permission from their employer before accepting compensation or other benefits from third parties for the services rendered to the employer or for any services that might create a conflict with their employer’s interest. Compensation and benefits include direct compensation by the client and any indirect compensation or other benefits received from third parties.
answerFeedback.d1e1f12c-cfd9-43fa-9061-d4459727ce12: Incorrect because according to Standard IV (B), Additional Compensation Arrangements, members must obtain permission from their employer before accepting compensation or other benefits from third parties for the services rendered to the employer or for any services that might create a conflict with their employer’s interest. Compensation and benefits include direct compensation by the client and any indirect compensation or other benefits received from third parties.

choices.itemBody: C. Both direct compensation and indirect compensation

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Ethics-Pitrakkou-25
entry.itemBody: Ana Kloes, CFA, passes all three levels of the CFA exam in three consecutive years. After passing the Level III exam, she adds to her email signature, "Partial CFA, awaiting CFA charter." Before Kloes is awarded the CFA charter, she writes on her social media page, "I passed all three levels of the CFA Program on my first attempt in three consecutive years." Has Kloes violated the Standards?

answerFeedback.152acc6c-7c48-4c7f-9af8-9f08fa4ae10d: Correct because according to Standard VII (B), Reference to CFA Institute, the CFA Designation, and the CFA Program, candidates must never state or imply that they have a partial designation as a result of passing one or more levels or cite an expected completion date of any level of the CFA Program. Final award of the charter is subject to meeting the CFA Program requirements and approval by the CFA Institute Board of Governors. Therefore she has violated the Standard by stating partial designation.
answerFeedback.1e3d3e3a-b433-4ef7-aba0-52fb26cab814: Incorrect because according to Standard VII (B), Reference to CFA Institute, CFA Designation, and CFA Program, this is not a violation. If a candidate passes each level of the exam in consecutive years and wants to state that he or she did so, that is not a violation of Standard VII(B) because it is a statement of fact. If the candidate then goes on to claim or imply superior ability by obtaining the designation in only three years, however, he or she is in violation of Standard VII(B).
answerFeedback.3aba312b-55a8-4d44-9dca-3d87aa9f36cb: Incorrect because according to Standard VII (B), Reference to CFA Institute, the CFA Designation, and the CFA Program, candidates must never state or imply that they have a partial designation as a result of passing one or more levels or cite an expected completion date of any level of the CFA Program. Final award of the charter is subject to meeting the CFA Program requirements and approval by the CFA Institute Board of Governors. Therefore she has violated the Standard by stating partial designation.

choices.itemBody: B. Yes, because she adds to her email signature, "Partial CFA, awaiting CFA charter"
C. Yes, because she adds on her social media page, "I passed all three levels of the CFA Program on my first attempt in three consecutive years"

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02329
entry.itemBody: To be compliant with the GIPS standards, after a firm presents five years of performance history, it must build up to a minimum of:

answerFeedback.03fc094f-08c8-47e4-81e8-ccd0adbc4b46: Incorrect because, as described in the response rationale for the correct answer, after a firm presents a minimum of five years of GIPS-compliant performances, the firm must present an additional year of performance each year, building up to a minimum of 10 years of GIPS-compliant performance, not 15 years of compliant performance.
answerFeedback.cc5b8ab0-b739-4050-9a65-583b9e0abb63: Incorrect because, as described in the response rationale for the correct answer, after a firm presents a minimum of five years of GIPS-compliant performances, the firm must present an additional year of performance each year, building up to a minimum of 10 years of GIPS-compliant performance, not 7 years of compliant performance.
answerFeedback.ec1b4a78-d212-46d6-bbeb-e4b63d942400: Correct because the GIPS standards state: A ﬁrm is required to initially present, at a minimum, ﬁve years of annual investment performance that is compliant with the GIPS standards. If the composite or pooled fund has been in existence less than ﬁve years, the ﬁrm must present performance since the composite or pooled fund inception date. Prospectively, the ﬁrm must present an additional year of performance each year, building up to a minimum of 10 years of GIPS-compliant performance.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Ethics-Agarwal-17
entry.itemBody: Akash Gupta has just finished taking the Level II CFA exam for the second time. To protect the integrity of the exam, Gupta is careful not to discuss the exam questions with other candidates. Gupta calls his friend, a member, and contrasts his two attempts by highlighting that there were many calculation questions on derivatives in the first instance and none in the second. Later, in a public blog on investment education, Gupta shares his strong disagreement regarding CFA Institute shifting to computer-based testing. Has Gupta violated the Standards?

answerFeedback.8a4d0855-a285-4e23-950b-0afb540a76eb: Incorrect because Standard VII(A) relating to Conduct as Participants in CFA Institute Programs does not cover expressing opinions regarding CFA Institute, the CFA Program, or other CFA Institute programs. Members and candidates are free to disagree and express their disagreement with CFA Institute on its policies, its procedures, or any advocacy positions taken by the organization.
answerFeedback.c0450719-d1ec-4033-86b5-dda05d972844: Correct because according to Standard VII(A) relating to Conduct as Participants in CFA Institute Programs, examples of information that cannot be disclosed by candidates sitting for an exam include but are not limited to broad topical areas and formulas tested or not tested on the exam.  Gupta has violated Standard VII(A).
answerFeedback.f1b63e6d-1d7a-4905-a3ae-e71d33d57186: Incorrect because according to Standard VII(A) relating to Conduct as Participants in CFA Institute Programs, examples of information that cannot be disclosed by candidates sitting for an exam include but are not limited to broad topical areas and formulas tested or not tested on the exam. Gupta has violated Standard VII(A).

choices.itemBody: B. Yes, by highlighting that there were no calculation questions on derivatives in the recent exam
C. Yes, by expressing his disagreement in a public blog regarding CFA Institute shifting to computer-based testing

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Ethics-Lee-03
entry.itemBody: A member who pays a higher brokerage commission on behalf of all of his clients than he would normally pay, without any corresponding benefit to the client, violates the Standard relating to:

answerFeedback.26e36a40-b99e-4f20-9e49-a80f123aa786: Incorrect because according to Standard III (B), Fair Dealing, Members and Candidates must deal fairly and objectively with all clients when providing investment analysis, making investment recommendations, taking investment action, or engaging in other professional activities. All clients are treated in the same way, so the Standard relating to fair dealing is not violated. The member violated Standard III(A), Loyalty, Prudence and Care.
answerFeedback.2b1ee014-6ffb-4417-946c-3da0c77b1e84: Correct because according to Standard III(A), Loyalty, Prudence, and Care, a member or candidate who pays a higher brokerage commission than he or she would normally pay to allow for the purchase of goods or services, without corresponding benefit to the client, violates the duty of loyalty to the client.
answerFeedback.4046d43d-d61b-41f4-80e0-e6d4549d5bfd: Incorrect because Standard III (C), Suitability, requires that members and candidates who are in an investment advisory relationship with clients consider carefully the needs, circumstances, and objectives of the clients when determining the appropriateness and suitability of a given investment or course of investment action. This scenario does not involve investment recommendation. The member violated Standard III(A), Loyalty, Prudence, and Care.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-Ethics-Bangaruswamy-06
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements is accurate?

answerFeedback.5a99273d-aba5-4866-8bbe-43063b2e1c0a: Correct because according to the GIPS standards, verification provides assurance on whether the firm’s policies and procedures related to composite and pooled fund maintenance, as well as the calculation, presentation, and distribution of performance, have been designed in compliance with the GIPS standards and have been implemented on a firm-wide basis.
answerFeedback.7c7b102d-4ffc-4878-b026-8347a339f79a: Incorrect because according to the GIPS standards, verification is performed with respect to an entire firm, not on specific composites. Verification does not ensure the accuracy of any specific composite presentation.
answerFeedback.ad6aa9d4-99df-4921-a3c1-a187eb644cb5: Incorrect because the GIPS standards certainly do not eliminate the need for in-depth due diligence on the part of the investor, but compliance with the Standards enhances the credibility of investment management firms that have chosen to undertake this responsibility. Also, once a firm claims compliance with the standards, they may voluntarily hire an independent third party to perform a verification in order to increase confidence in the firm’s claim of compliance. Therefore, verification enhances confidence in a firm's claim of compliance and compliance with the GIPS standards enhances credibility of the firm, but does not eliminate the need for in-depth due diligence of the firm for a prospective investor.

choices.itemBody: A. Verification eliminates the need for in-depth due diligence of a GIPS-compliant firm for a prospective investor.
B. Verification can be performed on a specific composite to ensure accuracy of the composite presentation.
C. Verification provides assurance on whether the firm’s policies and procedures related to pooled fund maintenance have been implemented on a firm-wide basis.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Ethics-Augulyte-03
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is not a recommended procedure for compliance with the Standard relating to misrepresentation? Firms should:

answerFeedback.247eefc5-9d8b-4793-bbd2-c8f76b985af4: Incorrect because firms can assist member and candidate compliance by periodically reviewing employee correspondence and documents that contain representations of individual or firm qualifications.
answerFeedback.2a7fb690-2ab2-4c03-b658-857c09375b5d: Correct because when providing information to clients from a third party, members and candidates share a responsibility for the accuracy of the marketing and distribution materials that pertain to the third party’s capabilities, services, and products. Misrepresentation by third parties can damage the member’s or candidate’s reputation, the reputation of the firm, and the integrity of the capital markets. Members and candidates should encourage their employers to develop procedures for verifying information of third-party firms. So, the recommendation is to verify information, but not to avoid verifying it.
answerFeedback.8814c17d-f4cb-46c4-94de-24b9f7d2f835: Incorrect because firms can also help prevent misrepresentation by specifically designating which employees are authorized to speak on behalf of the firm.

choices.itemBody: A. avoid verifying information from third-party firms for timely trade executions.
B. specifically designate which employees are authorized to speak on behalf of the firm.
C. periodically review employee correspondence that contains representations of individual qualifications.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Ethics-Ebeling-12
entry.itemBody: A member who is an investment advisor receives a large unsolicited trade request from a client that is not aligned with the client's investment objectives. Which of the following actions by the member is consistent with the Standard relating to suitability? The member:

answerFeedback.26041196-b540-44b8-9018-a120a66de150: Incorrect because according to Standard III (C), Suitability, in cases of unsolicited trade requests that a member or candidate knows are unsuitable for a client, the member or candidate should refrain from making the trade until he or she discusses the concerns with the client. Therefore, the member should not immediately proceed with executing the trade. Although the curriculum discusses smaller unsolicited trade requests as being less serious than large trades, it does not suggest that members unilaterally reduce the size of the trade and execute it without discussion with the client.
answerFeedback.c8430a43-ea96-4f05-9911-25ad5db0ca0a: Correct because according to Standard III (C), Suitability, in discussing the trade, the member or candidate should focus on educating the investor on how the request deviates from the current policy statement. Should the unsolicited request be expected to have a material impact on the portfolio, the member or candidate should use this opportunity to update the investment policy statement. Therefore, this member action is consistent with the Standard.
answerFeedback.d1acbf65-08ff-45f6-945f-a96363b102cd: Incorrect because according to Standard III (C), Suitability, in cases of unsolicited trade requests that a member or candidate knows are unsuitable for a client, the member or candidate should refrain from making the trade until he or she discusses the concerns with the client. Therefore, the member should not immediately proceed with executing the trade.

choices.itemBody: B. reduces the size of the requested investment and executes the trade.
C. discusses the investment with the client, adjusts the client's investment policy statement, and executes the trade.

entry.title: ITEM_20170420150
entry.itemBody: When a client asks her how she makes investment decisions, Petra Vogler, CFA, tells the client she uses mosaic theory. According to Vogler, the theory involves analyzing public and nonmaterial nonpublic information including the evaluation of statements made to her by company insiders in one-on-one meetings where management discusses new earnings projections not known to the public. Vogler also gathers general industry information from industry experts she has contacted. Vogler violates the CFA Institute Standards of Professional Conduct because of her use of:

answerFeedback.5bcbc384-ed43-4a51-bf91-d7c499fd3654: Incorrect because under the mosaic theory it is acceptable to use information from industry contacts as long as the analyst uses appropriate methods to arrive at her conclusions.
answerFeedback.b1738cb2-59df-4605-85e7-020e7bc6b5ec: Correct because Vogler violated Standard II(A), Material Nonpublic Information, by using information not known to the public that is selectively disclosed by company insiders in one-on-one meetings. Earnings estimates would likely be considered material and nonpublic information. Information made available to analysts remains nonpublic until it is made available to investors in general. Under the mosaic theory it is acceptable to use information from industry contacts as long as the analyst uses appropriate methods to arrive at her conclusions.
answerFeedback.f21e94ce-fe34-4d69-866b-7bbbf497e014: Incorrect because it is acceptable to use nonmaterial nonpublic information in her analysis, and this use is not a violation of Standard II(A), Material Nonpublic Information.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Ethics-Agarwal-18
entry.itemBody: Shruti Kurup, CFA, is preparing to leave her firm and join a new employer. Prior to leaving the firm, Kurup calls all her clients informing them of her decision to leave. When asked by the clients, Kurup states lack of confidence in the firm's leadership as the reason for her departure and also mentions that more employees are likely to leave soon. Kurup has violated the Standard(s) relating:

answerFeedback.0e94b153-3a17-4f54-99ea-a60f054db8a3: Incorrect because according to Standard V(B) relating to communication with clients and prospective clients, members and candidates should communicate in a recommendation the factors that were instrumental in making the investment recommendation. There is no investment recommendation being discussed here and hence the Standard is not violated.
answerFeedback.a2f52b90-a11e-45a6-a1da-a5e54ddceb48: Correct because Standard IV(A): Duties to Employers, Loyalty states that CFA Institute members and candidates must act for the benefit of their employer and not otherwise cause harm to their employer. Kurup violates her duty of loyalty to her employer by making disparaging and harmful statements about the firm to its clients. Kurup can call her clients to inform of her decision but cannot make disparaging statements about her employer. Also according to Standard V(B) relating to communication with clients and prospective clients, members and candidates should communicate in a recommendation the factors that were instrumental in making the investment recommendation. There is no investment recommendation being discussed here and hence the Standard is not violated. Only the Standard relating to loyalty has been violated.
answerFeedback.f6144dd5-26ae-41a0-8bc4-4e4f5a1417ea: Incorrect because according to Standard V(B) relating to communication with clients and prospective clients, members and candidates should communicate in a recommendation the factors that were instrumental in making the investment recommendation. There is no investment recommendation being discussed here and hence the Standard is not violated.

choices.itemBody: B. only to communication with clients and prospective clients.
C. both to loyalty and to communication with clients and prospective clients only.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Ethics-Lamba-01
entry.itemBody:
To comply with the Standard relating to knowledge of the law, members are required to take which of the following actions?

  • Action 1: Acquire detailed knowledge of all the laws relating to their activities
  • Action 2: Dissociate from activities of others that they believe are unethical

answerFeedback.46a3e8e8-d232-4c09-ad6b-28ea6e710172: Incorrect because according to Standard I(A), Knowledge of the Law, members and candidates must understand the applicable laws and regulations of the countries and jurisdictions where they engage in professional activities. However, members and candidates are not required to have detailed knowledge of or be experts on all the laws that could potentially govern their activities. So, members are not required to take Action 1. Also, if a member or candidate has reasonable grounds to believe that imminent or ongoing client or employer activities are illegal or unethical, the member or candidate must dissociate, or separate, from the activity. So, members are required to take only Action 2.
answerFeedback.bfc8df6d-76da-46f0-a28d-8e132ca19700: Incorrect because according to Standard I(A), Knowledge of the Law, members and candidates must understand the applicable laws and regulations of the countries and jurisdictions where they engage in professional activities. However, members and candidates are not required to have detailed knowledge of or be experts on all the laws that could potentially govern their activities. So, members are not required to take Action 1.
answerFeedback.fc0af253-c871-4f6d-802d-60eca2e57f2f: Correct because according to Standard I(A), Knowledge of the Law, if a member or candidate has reasonable grounds to believe that imminent or ongoing client or employer activities are illegal or unethical, the member or candidate must dissociate, or separate, from the activity. So, members are required to take Action 2.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Ethics-Lin-03
entry.itemBody: Peter Chang, CFA, spreads rumors on social media about a potential acquisition of Advanced Electronics Company (AEC) after buying the stock for his personal account. Despite the rumors, AEC's stock price declines and Chang closes his position at a significant loss. Has Chang violated the Standards?

answerFeedback.47e9e96b-d979-4627-b8b4-db54ec3c1f99: Incorrect because Standard I(D), Misconduct, addresses all conduct that reflects poorly on the professional integrity, good reputation, or competence of members and candidates. Any act that involves lying, cheating, stealing, or other dishonest conduct is a violation of this standard if the offense reflects adversely on a member’s or candidate’s professional activities. Spreading rumors on social media to push up the stock price reflects poorly on Chang's professional integrity. Therefore, Chang has also violated the Standard I(D), Misconduct.
answerFeedback.8764e0c2-6032-4cef-b388-785572ae0fb5: Incorrect because spreading rumors on social media to push up the stock price after buying the stock for his personal account reflects poorly on Chang's professional integrity. Therefore, Chang has violated both the Standard II(B), Market Manipulation and the Standard I(D), Misconduct.
answerFeedback.b34525d5-ce56-4d23-aab0-5863dd7db945:
Correct because according to Standard II(B), Market Manipulation, information-based manipulation includes, but is not limited to, spreading false rumors to induce trading by others. For example, members and candidates must refrain from “pumping up” the price of an investment by issuing misleading positive information or overly optimistic projections of a security’s worth only to later “dump” the investment (i.e., sell it) once the price, fueled by the misleading information’s effect on other market participants, reaches an artificially high level. Chang spreads rumors on social media about a potential acquisition of AEC after buying the stock for his personal account. Therefore, Chang has violated the Standard II(B), Market Manipulation.

In addition, Standard I(D), Misconduct, addresses all conduct that reflects poorly on the professional integrity, good reputation, or competence of members and candidates. Any act that involves lying, cheating, stealing, or other dishonest conduct is a violation of this standard if the offense reflects adversely on a member’s or candidate’s professional activities. Spreading rumors on social media to push up the stock price reflects poorly on Chang's professional integrity. Therefore, Chang has violated the Standard I(D), Misconduct.

choices.itemBody: B. Yes, the Standard relating to market manipulation only
C. Yes, both the Standard relating to market manipulation and the Standard relating to misconduct

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Ethics-Lin-10
entry.itemBody:
According to the Standards, which of the following information requires disclosure?

• Information 1: A member's brother inherits a significant ownership of a stock that is part of the member's research coverage universe. The member has no beneficial ownership in her brother's investments.

• Information 2: A member, a portfolio manager at an investment firm, does unpaid volunteer work during holiday weekends at a charity.

• Information 3: Firm enters into an agreement with a mutual fund to receive commissions for recommending the fund to the firm's clients.

answerFeedback.6ecfdb9e-7a47-4d52-8e9a-6de912c3fc6f: Correct because according to Standard VI(A), Avoid or Disclose Conflicts, disclosures must be made to clients regarding conflicts that may arise in fee arrangements, subadvisory agreements, or other situations involving nonstandard fee structures. Equally important is the disclosure of arrangements in which the firm benefits directly from investment recommendations. Therefore, Information 3 is required to be disclosed, because the firm benefits directly from its recommendation to invest in a certain mutual fund.
answerFeedback.74e78c2d-71fa-4b62-b93f-af782b2eb210: Incorrect because according to Standard VI(A), Avoid or Disclose Conflicts, situations that must be reported to employers include conflicts that would interfere with rendering unbiased investment advice and conflicts that would cause a member or candidate to act not in the employer’s best interest. In this case, the member does unpaid volunteer work at a charity during holiday weekends which is her personal time. It does not have conflicts of interest to her employers. Therefore, Information 2 is not required to be disclosed.
answerFeedback.b7512216-30d3-471d-8271-7d37fc658c86: Incorrect because according to Standard VI(A), Avoid or Disclose Conflicts, members and candidates must disclose any materially beneficial ownership interest in a security or other investment that the member or candidate is recommending. The member has no beneficial ownership in her brother's investments. Therefore, Information 1 is not required to be disclosed.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Ethics-Lin-03
entry.itemBody: According to the Standards, a member engages in information-based manipulation when she:

answerFeedback.447ca200-c57b-4906-9eb5-4c28e9bd8037: Incorrect because according to the Standard relating to market manipulation, information-based manipulation includes, but is not limited to, spreading false rumors to induce trading by others. The member relies on the false rumors existing in the market instead of spreading it. Therefore, she does not engage in information-based manipulation.
answerFeedback.a4ac2462-5c06-4def-853d-fc91a671e39b: Correct because according to the Standard relating to market manipulation, information-based manipulation includes spreading false rumors to induce trading by others. In this case, the member spreads a false rumor by issuing overly optimistic projections to induce other market participants to trade a security; therefore, the member engages in information-based manipulation.
answerFeedback.da009a47-cdf4-4245-a727-b653f6d2db7b: Incorrect because the Standard relating to market manipulation is not intended to preclude transactions undertaken on legitimate trading strategies based on perceived market inefficiencies. Therefore, using public information to implement trading strategies to exploit perceived market inefficiencies is not an example of information-based manipulation.

choices.itemBody: A. uses public information to implement trading strategies with an intent to exploit perceived market inefficiencies.
B. induces other market participants to trade a security by issuing an overly optimistic projection of a security's value.
C. relies on false rumors spread by other market participants to secure a dominant position in an underlying security.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Ethics-Lee-08
entry.itemBody: According to the Standard relating to preservation of confidentiality, a member is required to maintain confidentiality of information communicated to her:

answerFeedback.89261b77-8972-416f-af8c-3d20503caeb3: Incorrect because Standard III(E), Preservation of Confidentiality requires that members and candidates preserve the confidentiality of information communicated to them by their clients, prospective clients, and former clients.
answerFeedback.aeac0f8f-9f99-4a61-9f40-388b8fae65e8: Correct because Standard III(E), Preservation of Confidentiality requires that members and candidates preserve the confidentiality of information communicated to them by their clients, prospective clients, and former clients.
answerFeedback.f0bcdfcf-50bd-4549-8ca3-317f649671a7: Incorrect because Standard III(E), Preservation of Confidentiality requires that members and candidates preserve the confidentiality of information communicated to them by their clients, prospective clients, and former clients.

choices.itemBody: C. both by her former clients and by her prospective clients.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Ethics-Lamba-05
entry.itemBody: Anisha Joshi, CFA, develops a product that selects mutual funds based on historical data. Joshi tests her methodology and produces simulated performance results. The promotional material for the product does not indicate that the results are simulated. Joshi has most likely violated the Standards relating:

answerFeedback.15830184-2d4c-4b67-8a58-d9cc6f706910: Incorrect because according to Standard III(B), Fair Dealing, members and candidates must deal fairly and objectively with all clients when providing investment analysis, making investment recommendations, taking investment action, or engaging in other professional activities. There is nothing to suggest that Joshi has not dealt fairly and objectively with her clients. So, there is no violation of Standard III(B).
answerFeedback.4e1b11ef-f045-4b8a-afa3-57aeef555146: Correct because Standard III(D). Performance Presentation, requires members and candidates to provide credible performance information to clients and prospective clients and to avoid misstating performance or misleading clients and prospective clients about the investment performance of members or candidates or their firms. This standard encourages full disclosure of investment performance data to clients and prospective clients. By not disclosing that the results related to the product were simulated Joshi has violated the Standard.
answerFeedback.4fdc54c0-3db0-4f1d-86bf-fbc6886f2d07: Incorrect because according to Standard III(B), Fair Dealing, members and candidates must deal fairly and objectively with all clients when providing investment analysis, making investment recommendations, taking investment action, or engaging in other professional activities. There is nothing to suggest that Joshi has not dealt fairly and objectively with her clients. So, there is no violation of Standard III(B).

choices.itemBody: C. both to fair dealing and to performance presentation.

entry.title: ITEM_20210122009
entry.itemBody: Who is most likely responsible for claiming and maintaining compliance with the CFA Institute Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS)?

answerFeedback.113451f5-711e-46fa-a046-b2e03502cd1b: Incorrect because GIPS compliance is the responsibility of the firm claiming compliance and is not done on a department or on an individual basis.
answerFeedback.969cb08b-a579-4a86-865d-df82610802b1: Correct because firms that claim compliance with the GIPS standards are responsible for their claim of compliance and for maintaining that compliance.
answerFeedback.eb33cfe8-2dc6-4c81-adf3-878f4f5bd5c6: Incorrect because an independent party is not responsible for the claim or for maintaining compliance. Independent third-party verifiers can be voluntarily hired by the firm claiming compliance to verify compliance.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Ethics-Bangaruswamy-08
entry.itemBody: Mila Roy, CFA, heads the research division of an investment firm. Roy sends a recommended stock list to all of her firm's clients along with a notification that a detailed report on each stock is available on request. Roy later calls only her premium fee-paying clients and discusses her recommendations. Such additional services are available for all clients willing to pay premium fees and is fully disclosed as part of the client agreement. Has Roy violated the Standards?

answerFeedback.61dd7442-d819-4c89-98ab-17335882f9d5: Incorrect because Standard III(B), Fair Dealing, requires CFA Institute members and candidates to deal fairly and objectively with all clients when providing investment analysis and making investment recommendations. It also requires that information about investment recommendations be disseminated in such a manner that all clients have a fair opportunity to act on the information. Roy distributes the recommended stock list to all clients simultaneously via email, giving each an opportunity to act on the information. Also, Roy is permitted to provide detailed reports to clients who pay a subscription fee for the service as long as (1) all clients are eligible to purchase the service and, (2) the different levels of service are disclosed to clients. Therefore, Roy has not violated Standard III(B).
answerFeedback.d69d85e3-6354-476d-ad36-b7bdf79fede6:
Correct because Standard III(B), Fair Dealing, requires CFA Institute members and candidates to deal fairly and objectively with all clients when providing investment analysis and making investment recommendations. It also requires that information about investment recommendations be disseminated in such a manner that all clients have a fair opportunity to act on the information. Roy distributes the recommended stock list to all clients simultaneously via email, giving each an opportunity to act on the information. Also, Roy is permitted to provide detailed reports to clients who pay a subscription fee for the service as long as (1) all clients are eligible to purchase the service and, (2) the different levels of service are disclosed to clients. Therefore, Roy has not violated Standard III(B).

Further, according to Standard V(B), Communication with Clients and Prospective Clients, if recommendations are contained in capsule form (such as a recommended stock list), members and candidates should notify clients that additional information and analyses are available from the producer of the report. Roy sends a recommended stock list to all of her firm's clients along with a notification that a detailed report on each stock is available on request. Therefore, Roy has also not violated Standard V(B).
answerFeedback.dc7b10f6-e344-41a1-a631-3c1e72c8f09c: Incorrect because according to Standard V(B), Communication with Clients and Prospective Clients, if recommendations are contained in capsule form (such as a recommended stock list), members and candidates should notify clients that additional information and analyses are available from the producer of the report. Roy sends a recommended stock list to all of her firm's clients along with a notification that a detailed report on each stock is available on request. Therefore, Roy has not violated Standard V(B).

choices.itemBody: B. Yes, the Standard relating to fair dealing
C. Yes, the Standard relating to communication with clients and prospective clients

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Ethics-Fang-01
entry.itemBody: The GIPS standards were created to prevent the:

answerFeedback.11d76b6d-5b37-4744-b947-09e81bc9ff75: Correct because the GIPS standards were created to prevent misleading practices such as cherry-picking representative accounts which is the selection a top-performing portfolio to represent the firm's overall investment results for a specific mandate.
answerFeedback.65c08822-c213-4803-87d0-565e45677de3: Incorrect because the GIPS standards were created to prevent survivorship bias which is presenting an 'average' performance history that excludes [not include] portfolios whose poor performance was weak enough to result in termination of the firm.
answerFeedback.c303eeda-91ef-4f52-b98d-c21ab3f7ab3a: Incorrect because the GIPS standards were created to allow for the comparison of consistent time periods to facilitate comparisons with other firms' results. It prevents misleading practices of varying time periods which are presenting performance for a selected time period during which the mandate produced excellent returns or out-performed its benchmarks - making comparison with other firms' results difficult or impossible.

choices.itemBody: A. comparison of comparable time periods with other firms' results.
B. selection of a top-performing portfolio to represent the firm's strategy.
C. presentation of an average performance history that includes terminated portfolios.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Ethics-Lee-08
entry.itemBody: According to the Standard relating to responsibilities of supervisors, a member who works as a department head managing large numbers of employees must:

answerFeedback.60926748-094d-4700-b3df-f6f1e5301d79: Correct because according to Standard IV(C), Responsibilities of Supervisors, members and candidates acting as supervisors must also have in-depth knowledge of the Code and Standards.
answerFeedback.6112e557-d0ef-47ba-9c3b-85177c87d31f: Incorrect because according to Standard IV(C), Responsibilities of Supervisors, members and candidates with oversight responsibilities for large numbers of employees may not be able to personally evaluate the conduct of these employees on a continuing basis. These members and candidates may delegate supervisory duties to subordinates who directly oversee the other employees.
answerFeedback.84b68bf4-b6dc-4545-b7e5-49f49d631932: Incorrect because according to Standard IV(C), Responsibilities of Supervisors, members and candidates must make reasonable efforts to ensure that anyone subject to their supervision or authority complies with applicable laws, rules, regulations, and the Code and Standards. Therefore, the member is not required to make reasonable efforts to ensure all employees at his firm comply with applicable laws and regulations.

choices.itemBody: A. have in-depth knowledge of the Code and Standards.
B. personally evaluate the conduct of all employees in his department on a continuing basis.
C. make reasonable efforts to ensure all employees at his firm comply with applicable laws and regulations.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Ethics-Pitrakkou-28
entry.itemBody: Regarding challenges to ethical behavior, which of the following is not an example of a situational influence?

answerFeedback.5ea6217e-9708-46b2-bda8-d1648e2fcaf5: Incorrect because this is an example of a situational influence. Bonuses, promotions, prestige, and loyalty to employer and colleagues are examples of situational influences that frequently have a disproportionate weight in our decision making.
answerFeedback.8166548b-3965-4d39-9f3e-02cbedc33992: Correct because situational influences are external factors, such as environmental or cultural elements, that shape our thinking, decision making, and behavior. Therefore, internal decision making factors does not fall within the definition of situational influences.
answerFeedback.cadb1c32-cb1f-4442-87ac-1f06d65c2428: Incorrect because this is an example of a situational influence. Bonuses, promotions, prestige, and loyalty to employer and colleagues are examples of situational influences that frequently have a disproportionate weight in our decision making.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Ethics-Lee-20
entry.itemBody: Mary Lawrence, CFA, is a research analyst. She archives her research notes for recommendation changes and discards her research notes for cases in which recommendations do not change. She also discards third-party research reports used to support her analysis. Lawrence has most likely violated the Standards:

answerFeedback.8905dece-e349-425f-8f3e-aa21eec21c9c: Incorrect as described in the response rationale of the correct answer.
answerFeedback.b68d96c1-facd-4708-8035-93f19a63299b: Correct because according to the Standard V(C), record retention, Members and candidates must retain records that substantiate the scope of their research and reasons for their actions or conclusions. The retention requirement applies to decisions to buy or sell a security as well as reviews undertaken that do not lead to a change in position. An example of supporting documentation that assists the member or candidate in meeting the requirements for retention are outside research reports.
answerFeedback.cd5083f8-3dff-47fa-a64d-140431cd724c: Incorrect as described in the response rationale of the correct answer.

choices.itemBody: A. only by discarding third-party research reports used to support her analysis.
B. only by discarding her research notes for cases in which recommendations do not change.
C. both by discarding third-party research reports used to support her analysis and by discarding her research notes for cases in which recommendations do not change.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10590
entry.itemBody: The central limit theorem:

answerFeedback.045f44e9-17fe-4e52-817e-ecfa4d09523b: Correct because the central limit theorem states that the variance of the distribution of the sample mean is σ2/n. The positive square root of variance is standard deviation. The standard deviation of a sample statistic is known as the standard error of the statistic. The sample mean, in addition to being an efficient estimator, is also a consistent estimator of the population mean: As sample size n goes to infinity, its standard error, σ/√n, goes to 0 and its sampling distribution becomes concentrated right over the value of population mean, µ.
answerFeedback.09c521de-24a4-4d0f-944d-41979a1eb67e: Incorrect because the central limit theorem states that the sum and mean (not the product) of a large number of independent random variables is approximately normally distributed.
answerFeedback.786439d6-a0e2-4f3b-962e-31199bc50827: Incorrect because the central limit theorem allows us to make quite precise probability statements about the population mean by using the sample mean, whatever the distribution of the population (so long as it has finite variance), because the sample mean follows an approximate normal distribution for large-size samples. Therefore, having a normally distributed population is not a requirement for the central limit theorem to hold.

choices.itemBody: A. requires that the population be approximately normally distributed.
B. implies that the sample mean is a consistent estimator of the population mean.
C. states that the product of independent random variables is normally distributed.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606080
entry.itemBody: A portfolio invested in two assets has an expected return of 11%. If expected returns for Assets A and B, respectively, are 8% and 12%, then the portfolio weight of Asset B is closest to:

answerFeedback.98a871a1-b14a-42f8-87f7-133ca34d19a9: Incorrect. A weight of 50% for Asset B implies a portfolio return of 10%.
answerFeedback.a8b10899-96da-4304-926a-bb1ddc88b3cb: Incorrect. This is the portfolio weight for Asset A. A weight of 25% for Asset B implies a portfolio return of 9%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.01-Quant-Zhang-16
entry.itemBody: In a test of independence based on contingency table data, the nonparametric test statistic to be used is:

answerFeedback.3e7b600b-c7e9-42b1-b92b-95328a451c9b: Incorrect because if we want to test whether there is a relationship between the size and investment type (two classifications in a contingency table), we can perform a test of independence using a nonparametric test statistic that is chi-square distributed.
answerFeedback.3e7b6df6-40a6-4cd6-adc7-5bde36203a77: Correct because if we want to test whether there is a relationship between the size and investment type (two classifications in a contingency table), we can perform a test of independence using a nonparametric test statistic that is chi-square distributed.
answerFeedback.a6416e53-06d3-43b3-a8b3-cf000c8da5de: Incorrect because if we want to test whether there is a relationship between the size and investment type (two classifications in a contingency table), we can perform a test of independence using a nonparametric test statistic that is chi-square distributed.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-FRA-Roberts-17
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information (in £ millions) about a company:

Beginning accounts receivable 5,500
Ending accounts receivable 7,000
Revenue 35,000

Assuming all sales are made on credit, cash received from customers (in £ millions) is:

answerFeedback.449ccf76-5825-49a6-87da-ac22ee22abb8: Incorrect because it reverses the Beginning and Ending accounts receivable in the calculation. The calculation becomes 7,000 + 35,000 – 5,500 = 36,500.
answerFeedback.646d8c83-f1db-4148-be0a-90aa24e3f49b: Correct because to determine the approximate cash receipts from its customers, it is necessary to adjust this revenue amount by the net change in accounts receivable for the year. If accounts receivable increase during the year, revenue on an accrual basis is higher than cash receipts from customers, and vice versa. Cash received from customers = Beginning accounts receivable + Revenue – Ending accounts receivable. The calculation becomes 5,500 + 35,000 – 7,000 = 33,500.
answerFeedback.bb813afd-018c-4b5c-a7c1-a3794db822b0: Incorrect because it assumes that revenue received is all in cash. On a company's balance sheet, the item “trade receivables” or “accounts receivable” would indicate that a company provides credit to its customers.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-CorpIssuers-Harper-08
entry.itemBody: Double taxation of income occurs when a corporation pays taxes on its profits, and additional taxes are paid by the:

answerFeedback.8143ff8d-9efd-4a3c-84c8-a471507e2241: Incorrect because the gains earned is not a form of income, but a change in the value of the ownership share.
answerFeedback.9aaf1745-446c-40f7-b971-21367f87c0aa: Correct because double taxation is when shareholders pay an additional tax on distributions (dividends) that are passed on to them.
answerFeedback.a2e54499-133f-49d7-a6e4-d4cd176da465: Incorrect because the second tax is paid by the shareholders, not the corporation, based on personal income (dividends) received.

choices.itemBody: C. shareholders on gains earned from their equity investment.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02155
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following fiscal year information (in ¥ millions) for a company:

Cash flow from operating activities 28,808
Purchase of equipment 1,300
Sale of equipment 1,750
Long-term debt repayment 470
Increase in short-term borrowing 930

FCFE is closest to:

answerFeedback.30aeef7e-350e-46b3-b695-2bb57f85b633:
Incorrect because the calculation does not take into account the net debt repayment.

¥29,258 = ¥28,808 – ¥1,300 + ¥1,750.
answerFeedback.53236ddc-5b23-4622-a36c-aa023dc15c79:
Incorrect because the calculation adds net debt repayment when it should subtract it.

¥28,798 = ¥28,808 – ¥1,300 + ¥1,750 – (–¥470 + ¥930)
answerFeedback.b769792b-4d87-44d3-b2f3-33132e6fd64f:
Correct because FCFE is the cash flow available to the company's common stockholders after all operating expenses and borrowing costs (principal and interest) have been paid and necessary investments in working capital and fixed capital have been made. FCFE can be computed as

FCFE = CFO – FCInv + net borrowing

Where:

CFO = Cash flow from operating activities

FCInv = Capital expenditures (fixed capital, such as equipment)

FCFE = ¥28,808 – ¥1,300 + ¥1,750 – ¥470 + ¥930 = ¥29,718.

entry.title: ITEM_20170531031
entry.itemBody: A positive movement in a lagging indicator would least likely be used to:

answerFeedback.2d81f430-c18a-4406-9571-16747037e2c3: Incorrect because a positive move in a lagging indicator is most likely identifying an upturn in economic activity that occurred in the past.
answerFeedback.79b228e0-59ca-4dcd-a970-0374bdaf2c71: Incorrect because a positive move in a lagging indicator by itself is insufficient to indicate a positive expansion. However, confirmation would be required from positive changes in a coincident indicator to indicate expansion.
answerFeedback.aed94b21-895a-468e-a6d7-97720d9e350d: Correct because a positive movement in a lagging indicator would most likely be used to confirm that an existing expansion is underway or has already occurred. Only a leading indicator would help identify or predict a future economic event.

choices.itemBody: A. identify a past condition of the economy.
B. identify an expected future economic upturn.
C. confirm that an expansion is currently underway.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.01-Econ-McDonald-05
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is an example of cooperative country behavior?

answerFeedback.1247e1a2-77b0-42ab-aef9-678ee78d5052: Incorrect because autarky describes countries seeking political self-sufficiency with little or no external trade or finance.
answerFeedback.7959ab27-c1c9-4474-8d32-7f384dc63b91: Correct because bilateralism is the conduct of political, economic, financial, or cultural cooperation between two countries.
answerFeedback.fbad162a-49cd-41b1-b64e-510a5a10c261: Incorrect because hegemonic countries tend to be regional or even global leaders, and they use their political or economic influence of others to control resources. State-owned enterprises tend to control key export markets.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Econ-Erickson-01
entry.itemBody: A firm is operating under an oligopoly when it is:

answerFeedback.19e25399-fb43-484a-b402-f8ff7a640ed1: Correct because the oligopoly market structure is based on a relatively small number of firms supplying the market.
answerFeedback.4d11c6cb-3cb9-4833-9940-e61feb9c73d0: Incorrect because a single provider of a good or service is representative of a monopoly, not an oligopoly. In pure monopoly markets, there are no other good substitutes for the given product or service. There is a single seller, which, if allowed to operate without constraint, exercises considerable power over pricing and output decisions.
answerFeedback.4e0a7a0f-02ba-4ba8-9d36-9735dd45be87: Incorrect because one or many providers of a good or service is representative of both monopolistic competition and perfect competition, not an oligopoly. Monopolistic competition is also highly competitive. The competitive characteristic is a notably large number of firms. Similarly, perfect competition is a reality—for example, in several commodities markets, where sellers and buyers have a strictly homogeneous product and no single producer is large enough to influence market prices. Product differentiation is not possible.

choices.itemBody: A. the sole provider of a good or service.
B. one of many providers of a good or service.
C. one of a small number of providers of a good or service.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-FRA-Teo-02
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information (in € millions) about a company’s machine:

Carrying amount prior to impairment 8.0
Present value of expected future cash flows 7.4
Undiscounted expected future cash flows 7.8
Costs to sell 0.2
Impairment loss 0.5

The fair value of the machine (in € millions) is:

answerFeedback.5d145314-7447-42c3-87e9-a917554d3df6:
Correct because under IFRS, an asset's recoverable amount is the higher of its fair value less costs to sell and its value in use. Expressing this in the form of an equation:  Recoverable amount = max[(Fair value – Costs to sell); Value in use] = max[(Fair value – €0.2 million); €7.4 million].

Given that under IAS 36, an impairment loss is measured as the excess of carrying amount over the recoverable amount of the asset, the recoverable amount can also be calculated as carrying value less impairment loss. Expressing this as an equation:

Recoverable amount = Carrying value – Impairment loss = €(8.0 – 0.5) million = €7.5 million

Equating equations 1 & 2: max[(Fair value –​​​​​​ €0.2 million); €7.4 million] = €7.5 million

Fair value = €7.5 million + €0.2 million = €7.7 million.
answerFeedback.a6c2f245-6375-4196-9a74-e6328d1dfc41: Incorrect because this answer assumes that fair value is the carrying amount less costs to sell = €(8.0 – 0.2) million = €7.8 million. Instead, under IFRS, an impairment loss is measured as the excess of carrying amount over the recoverable amount of the asset, while the asset's recoverable amount is the higher of its fair value less costs to sell and its value in use.
answerFeedback.d0a375db-72e3-476c-ad4e-fa1b8f745905:
Incorrect because this answer is based on US GAAP, which measures impairment loss as the difference between the asset’s fair value and carrying amount if the carrying amount of the asset is considered not recoverable. The carrying amount of an asset 'group' is considered not recoverable when it exceeds the undiscounted expected future cash flows of the group. 

According to US GAAP, Fair value of the asset = Carrying amount – Impairment loss = €(8.0 – 0.5) million = €7.5 million.

entry.title: ITEM_20170531143
entry.itemBody: An advantage of indirect taxes as a fiscal policy tool is that such taxes:

answerFeedback.0f8f56da-c078-4065-8dc1-bb8045fdd833: Correct because indirect taxes, which are taxes on spending including excise taxes on fuel, alcohol, and tobacco as well as taxes on gambling winnings, can be adjusted almost immediately after they are announced and can influence spending behavior instantly.
answerFeedback.5e5aab88-53ef-46b6-94b7-0ca5e2178e30: Incorrect because direct government spending has a far bigger impact on aggregate spending and output than tax cuts or transfer increases.
answerFeedback.6b285382-937a-41bc-a4ff-3107565a1ebb: Incorrect because indirect taxes support social policies that are specifically aimed at influencing and deterring consumer choices related to such consumption and activities.

choices.itemBody: C. have a greater impact on aggregate spending and output than direct government spending.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-FRA-Mazararu-12
entry.itemBody: The notes to the financial statements are required to provide:

answerFeedback.09cbb182-730a-4c95-98d3-c7bab3e652bf: Incorrect because it is not a requirement to provide information about every line item and for many companies, the financial notes and supplemental schedules provide explanatory information about every line item (or almost every line item) on the balance sheet and income statement.
answerFeedback.160d4472-2780-4f91-8849-c1504e96b690: Correct because the notes disclose information about the accounting policies, methods, and estimates used to prepare the financial statements.
answerFeedback.8e91cdd0-7ae4-49c0-ad1f-8cead2a45cc0: Incorrect because management highlights are covered by the management commentary or management’s discussion and analysis (MD&A) and not the financial notes. Also, in the United States, the SEC requires listed companies to provide an MD&A and specifies the content. Management must highlight any favorable or unfavorable trends and identify significant events and uncertainties that affect the company’s liquidity, capital resources, and results of operations.

choices.itemBody: A. explanatory information about every line item on the balance sheet and income statement.
B. information about the accounting policies, methods, and estimates used to prepare the financial statements.
C. management comments over any favorable or unfavorable trends, significant events and uncertainties that may affect the company.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.01-CorpIssuers-Croitoru-05
entry.itemBody: At which stage in its life cycle would a typical company most likely have more debt than equity in its capital structure?

answerFeedback.3062298b-83ee-454e-b7ca-ffc13ec9d764: Incorrect because as a company exits the growth stage and progresses through the growth stage, debt financing might become more accessible, but the company might want to use debt conservatively and continue relying primarily on equity financing. Both the availability and the terms of debt financing improve for the company during this stage. Many growth companies use debt conservatively in order to preserve operational and financial flexibility and minimize the risk of financial distress. Equity remains the predominant source of capital.
answerFeedback.66aada3c-b698-4a01-9061-9e04ab45bc96: Incorrect because at this early stage, debt capital is typically not available or available only at a high cost. From the perspective of an early-stage issuer, debt may be an attractive way to reduce or avoid the dilution associated with equity issuance. However, with cash flows that are negative and unpredictable, a typical start-up would have difficulty making regular debt payments, or 'servicing the debt.' Even if debt is available, the cost, inflexibility, and risk associated with borrowing are often unattractive to a start-up. As a result, debt is a negligible component of the capital structures of most start-up companies.
answerFeedback.67b55916-bbe0-4119-8ce2-12c5e903abfa: Correct because at the mature stage, the company becomes able to support low-cost debt, often on an unsecured basis. From the company’s perspective, debt financing is likely to be more attractive than higher-cost equity financing. Also, as companies mature, business risk typically declines, and their cash flows turn positive and become increasingly predictable, allowing for greater use of leverage on more attractive (less costly) financing terms. Debt then becomes a larger component of their capital structures.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.08-CorpIssuers-Tsependa-14
entry.itemBody: Business models should have:

answerFeedback.0d047d0d-196e-4a20-b447-4969ddc97090: Incorrect because key questions to better ascertain a business model are: "What is the firm’s value proposition to its target customer(s)?" and "What is the firm’s value chain?" Thus, both, value proposition and value chain are components or aspects of a firm's business model.
answerFeedback.75aedaa0-bf2c-4251-a9a1-f2115c2c9cf6: Correct because key questions to better ascertain a business model are: "What is the firm’s value proposition to its target customer(s)?" and "What is the firm’s value chain?" Thus, both, value proposition and value chain are components or aspects of a firm's business model.
answerFeedback.aac21423-e193-42b6-83fe-f550e3b79864: Incorrect because key questions to better ascertain a business model are: "What is the firm’s value proposition to its target customer(s)?" and "What is the firm’s value chain?" Thus, both, value proposition and value chain are components or aspects of a firm's business model.

choices.itemBody: C. both a value chain and a value proposition.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.03-CorpIssuers-Garcia-Huidobro-13
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a company's capital investment:

Initial cash outlay $90 million
Annual before-tax cash flows (year-end) for Year 1 through Year 6 $50 million
Marginal tax rate 15%
Required rate of return 12%

The net present value of the investment is closest to:

answerFeedback.172939a1-7df8-4797-b5c2-ea3f3fdfb9a0:
Correct because for a capital investment with one investment outlay, made initially, the net present value (NPV) is the present value of the future after-tax cash flows minus the investment outlay NPV = t=1nΣCFt /(1 + r)t − Outlay

We calculate the present value of the future after-tax cash flows using the calculator with the following parameters:

Yearly after-tax payment/cash-flow: PMT = 50 × (1 – 0.15) = 42.5

Number of payments: N = 6

Int. rate = 12%,

To calculate the NPV, from the present value we subtract the initial $90 million outflow. Accordingly, NPV = $174.7 million – $90.0 million = $84.7 ≈ $85 million.
answerFeedback.3942ac66-ea25-41c3-9778-4dc1c1bb233c: Incorrect because it uses the before-tax cash flow of $50 million in the calculation (instead of the after-tax cash flow of $42.5 million). Calculating the present value of the cash flows with parameters PMT = 50, N = 6 and Int. Rate = 12% gives a present value of $205.57 million, and subtracting the initial $90 million outflow, the NPV is incorrectly calculated as NPV = $205.57 million – $90 million = $115.6 million ≈ $116 million.
answerFeedback.d3c86084-c7db-464e-a949-ff92229a5664: Incorrect because it omits the initial cash outlay. Accordingly, the NPV = $174.7 ≈ $175 million.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-FSAN-Erickson-13
entry.itemBody: An analyst is preparing financial projections for a company held in her firm's equity portfolio. When determining an appropriate time horizon for her company projections, the analyst should consider:

answerFeedback.5be685a8-1e5f-4ad9-ab34-99008fe4809e: Incorrect because the cyclicality of the industry could also influence the analyst's choice of time frame because the forecast period should be long enough to allow the business to reach an expected mid-cycle level of sales and profitability.
answerFeedback.cb45b0a6-47cc-4f8c-83ef-908d7ab425d6: Incorrect because the time frame should ideally correspond with average portfolio turnover of the portfolio.
answerFeedback.cd7d42e1-0337-4aeb-ace0-d7fc05f737bd: Correct because the time frame should ideally correspond with average portfolio turnover of the portfolio. Furthermore, the cyclicality of the industry could also influence the analyst's choice of time frame because the forecast period should be long enough to allow the business to reach an expected mid-cycle level of sales and profitability.

choices.itemBody: B. cyclicality of the company's industry only.
C. both the portfolio's turnover and the cyclicality of the company's industry.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-CorpFin-Moustra-09
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a company’s capital structure, cost of capital and marginal tax rate:

Market value of debt $1,000 million
Market value of equity $500 million
Book value of debt $900 million
Book value of equity $300 million
Pre-tax cost of debt 4%
Cost of equity 6%
Marginal tax rate 30%

If interest is fully tax deductible, the WACC is closest to:

answerFeedback.0d072f29-9756-4e95-a03e-818ac030d266: Incorrect because this response does not take into account the tax deductibility of interest, i.e. WACC = wdrd(1 – t) + wprp + were ≠ (1000/(1000+500)) × 0.04 + (500/(1000+500)) × 0.06  = 0.04667 ≈ 4.7%.
answerFeedback.66f5afa9-1d0a-42a2-84ef-25ed557215b3: Incorrect because this distractor incorrectly uses book values instead of market values to calculate weights. WACC = wdrd(1 – t) + wprp + were ≠ (900/(900 + 300)) × 0.04 × (1 – 0.30) + (300/(900+300)) × 0.06 = 0.036 = 3.6%.
answerFeedback.cfd4bfa7-bc60-47ee-94b5-93671d195867:
Correct because WACC = wdrd(1 – t) + wprp + were,

where

wd is the proportion of debt,

rd is the before-tax marginal cost of debt,

wp is the proportion of preferred stock,

rp is the marginal cost of preferred stock,

we is the proportion of equity, and

re is the marginal cost of equity.

Therefore WACC = (1000/(1000 + 500)) × (0.04)(1 – 0.30) + (500/(1000 + 500)) × 0.06  = 0.03867 ≈ 3.9%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Econ-Milosevic-02
entry.itemBody: The regulation of economic activity over time is associated with:

answerFeedback.25b37905-f72f-461d-ae0c-673f4f745212: Incorrect because both monetary and fiscal policies are used to regulate economic activity over time.
answerFeedback.76f0f429-1563-45b4-ab99-12939d11955b: Incorrect because both monetary and fiscal policies are used to regulate economic activity over time.
answerFeedback.a5354a6d-9610-4f8c-a6d4-0656b8b01e99: Correct because both monetary and fiscal policies are used to regulate economic activity over time.

choices.itemBody: C. both fiscal policy and monetary policy.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.01-Quant-Moustra-11
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following one-period continuously compounded returns.

r0,1 4.2%
r1,2 3.0%
r2,3 –1.0%

The continuously compounded return from time t = 0 to time t = 3 is closest to:

answerFeedback.3f3f108d-6c9a-49bd-8eb3-d7fd45d5ec7b: Incorrect because the candidate mistakenly assumes the values in the table are holding period returns and then uses the formula rt,t+1 = ln(1 + Rt,t+1) to convert them to one-period continuously compounded returns. Then, these are added to calculate the continuously compounded return to time T as r0,3 = r2,3 + r1,2 + r0,1 ≠ ln(1 – 1.0%) + ln(1 + 3.0%) + ln(1 + 4.2%) = –0.01005 + 0.02956 + 0.04114 = 0.06065 ≈ 6.07%.
answerFeedback.406cfdc7-16be-4515-a42e-6afba77d4054: Incorrect because the candidate does calculations for holding period returns. i.e r0,3 = {(1 + r0,1) × (1 + r2,3) × (1 + r1,2 )} – 1 = {(1 + 4.2%) × (1 + 3.0%) × (1 – 1.0%)} – 1 = (1.042 × 1.03 × 0.99) – 1 = 1.06253 – 1 = 0.06253 ≈ 6.25%.
answerFeedback.4335e70e-58a1-4c85-aed6-25743d3c1a6a: Correct because the continuously compounded return to time T is the sum of the one-period continuously compounded returns: r0,T = rT−1,T + rT−2,T−1 + . . . + r0,1. In this case, r0,3 = r2,3 + r1,2 + r0,1 = –1.0% + 3.0% + 4.2% = 6.20%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Quant-Tomter-05
entry.itemBody: An analyst runs a simple linear regression to test whether the variation in the demand for corn explains the variation in the supply of wheat. In this model, the demand for corn is a(n):

answerFeedback.392e7d64-d141-46ef-a630-ab02424db38f: Incorrect because variation in the demand for corn is being used to explain the variation in the supply of wheat. Therefore the variation in the supply of wheat is the dependent variable, or explained variable. We refer to the variable whose variation is being explained as the dependent variable, or the explained variable; it is typically denoted by Y.
answerFeedback.8ef15744-0dca-4430-95a9-afe62eb52b3e: Incorrect because demand for corn is not limited to values of 0 or 1. Suppose we want to examine whether a company’s quarterly earnings announcements influence its monthly stock returns.
